awd_titl_txt: Phylogeny, historical biogeography, and floral ecological-evolutionary-developmental studies in Mariposa lilies and relatives (Calochortus, Liliaceae)
awd_abstract_narration:
Mariposa lilies and relatives (Calochortus, family Liliaceae) are a genus of roughly 80 species of bulbous herbs.  Most Calochortus species are found in California but the group can also be found in other parts of western North America and Central America. Calochortus species occur in diverse habitats and have repeatedly evolved four striking floral syndromes (mariposas, cat's ears, star tulips, fairy lanterns) marked by differences in flower shape, color, hairiness, and whether flowers are nodding or erect. Most species are individually restricted to narrow geographic areas, and 25% are associated with serpentine soils. This project will examine the forces that have shaped both differences in flower appearance of this charismatic group and driven their geographic spread across the western US. The researchers will test theories for how different habitats may favor the different four floral syndromes, and evaluate whether the same or different genes or genetic pathways underlie the development of similar floral syndromes. The study will provide unique insights into the evolution of biological diversity by integrating ecology, evolution, genomics, development, and biogeography. Two post-doctoral researchers, two graduate students, and three undergraduates will be trained in diverse molecular biology, developmental and evolutionary techniques. Results from the study will be disseminated to the public via popular articles, outreach to K-12 teachers and students, and by developing teaching materials for a college-level laboratory study on floral evolution and California biogeography. Public displays on Calochortus diversity will be exhibited at the Rancho Santa Ana Botanical Garden and Cornell Botanic Gardens. A field course will provide college students with hands-on experience involving natural history collections, bioinformatics, and comparative biology. A multimedia presentation will be developed and shown on public TV, with excerpts posted on YouTube. All data will be made available publicly, including a database and dedicated website for the extensive genomic resources that will be developed.
 
This project will develop Calochortus as a model for macro- and microevolutionary studies by: (1) sequencing >350 low-copy nuclear loci and whole plastid genomes  to derive fully resolved, strongly supported phylogenies; (2) reconstructing trait evolution, climatic niche shifts, and historical biogeography, including investigating the implications of an apparent ring species complex in the Bay Area clade; (3) testing geographic-speciation theory by determining whether sister taxa show a significant tendency to have abutting/nearby ranges; and (4) conducting floral ecological-evolutionary-developmental studies that examine the genetic, developmental, and ecological bases for the cat's-ear and fairy-lantern floral syndromes. Researchers will use analyses of selection on candidate genes, gene expression and evolution of genetic networks, functional gene analysis through CRISPR genome editing and comparative studies of developmental allometry, climatic niches, and genomic data to better understand the mechanisms driving the recurrent evolution of floral traits in specific environmental contexts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

Calochortus is a large genus of bulbous plants native to the western United States and Mexico, with many species restricted to the winter-rainfall region within California (Fig. 1). Many species have narrow geographic ranges. One-quarter occur on or are restricted to serpentine; nearly as many are federally threatened or extinct, and thus of great interest to conservation biologists. We undertook this study to understand relationships and the evolution of flower form, habitat, and soil preference in this group, when and where it arose, how it spread across the landscape, and what were the primary factors responsible for the generation and maintenance of species diversity and its variation across western North America. Answering these questions for Calochortus might serve as a model for understanding plant diversification throughout western North America.

We developed evolutionary family trees (phylogenies) for Calochortus by obtaining and analyzing DNA sequences of 294 single-copy nuclear genes and the entire chloroplast genome for all 74 living species. Nuclear data identified six major lineages, each restricted to (or most diverse in) different geographic regions, including the Pacific Northwest, Bay Area, Rocky Mountains-Great Basin, California, Mexico, and the Transverse-Peninsular Ranges (Fig. 2). These lineages also mostly differ in the number of chromosome pairs, with n = 6-10. The lineages began diverging from each other roughly 10 million years ago, with species within individual lineages beginning to diverge 2.5 to 5 million years ago. Calochortus appears to have originated in the Rocky Mountains, Columbia Basin, and Cascades, and then spread into Mexico, the Great Basin, Sierra Nevada, Coast Ranges, and Transverse and Peninsular Ranges (Fig. 3). Relationships among lineages were quite similar in the nuclear and chloroplast phylogenies, but in some groups the constituent species were related in different ways in the two trees, apparently reflecting hybridization or incomplete fixation of gene differences during evolution. In addition, nuclear genes evolved more rapidly, providing more data with which to assess relationships more accurately.

Chromosome number underwent six shifts from an ancestral n=8 to n=6 (twice), 7, 8, 9 (secondarily), and 10 (Fig. 4). Species in lineages with different chromosome numbers cannot hybridize and – most likely as a result – overlap in their distributions in the Coast Ranges, Sierra Nevada, Transverse Ranges, Peninsular Ranges, and northern Rocky Mountains, contributing to local and global diversity in Calochortus. We estimate five origins and 13 losses of serpentine tolerance in the Pacific Northwest, Bay Area, Transverse-Peninsular, and Rocky Mountain-Great Basin clades, with gains all associated with serpentine outcrops in California, Oregon, and Washington (Fig. 4).

Speciation and coexistence of closely related species require reproductive isolation and ecological isolation, so we examined the roles of chromosome number, environmental heterogeneity, and migration in shaping local species richness. As predicted, local species number increased significantly with local heterogeneity in chromosome number, elevation, soil characteristics, and serpentine presence. Species richness and phylogenetic diversity are greatest in the Transverse/Peninsular Ranges where clades with different chromosome numbers overlap, topographic complexity provides diverse conditions over short distances, and several physiographic provinces meet allowing immigration by several lineages.

Recently divergent species generally have abutting or nearly abutting ranges, and geographic overlap between species increases over the first million years since divergence, suggesting that chromosomal evolution and genetic divergence leading to reproductive isolation and/or ecological divergence may permit co-occurrence of more distantly related species.

Broader impacts

This study is remarkable in being the only study of a large plant group in which the roles of both reproductive barriers and ecological divergence in permitting coexistence have been analyzed, and shown to have roughly equal effects on spatial variation in species richness and phylogenetic diversity. This validates Lack's principle – raised in connection with adaptive radiation and species diversification – that coexistence of closely related species requires both ecological isolation and reproductive isolation. Divergence in chromosome number has allowed up to three major lineages within Calochortus to overlap in some areas after they arose in isolation. Historical patterns of Calochortus diversification within California are similar to those recently for some other groups of California plants.

This project trained one post-doc, two graduate students, and one undergraduate in molecular phylogenetics and comparative methods.

We also collected and analyzed data on (1) a ring-species complex formed by genetic divergence, species formation, and geographic spread from the Bay Area into the mountains surrounding California; (2) discordance between nuclear and chloroplast DNA sequences and its likely origins; and (3) how closely related species with different flowers (fairy lanterns vs. cat’s ears) diverge in floral development.

Our Cornell colleagues – supported by a collaborative grant and aided by us – have sequenced genomes for five Calochortus species, including the first reference-quality sequence for the economically important lily family. They are analyzing gene expression at different stages of floral development in the cat’s-ear and fairy-lantern flowers we studied (see above).
